guide.conclusion:
The "tw_moth_anti-moth" program has a routine to allow you to zero your servos. By depressing the bumper switch within the first 2 seconds after robot start-up, the robot sends a continuous zero signal (1.5 ms pulse) to the servos. To leave the mode turn off the robot and restart.

You can also change the robot behavior from moth to anti-moth by changing a variable in the .c program file.

My experience is that the robot works best in lighting conditions that are not extreme. For example a moderately lit room during daytime with a light on. This situation provides for subtle shadows and interesting runs. A room flooded with light (night time with bright overhead lights) can saturate the sensors and cause the robot to just travel straight, since it can not sense enough difference between the directions.

guide.introduction:
Adding CdS photocell sensors to your Tiny Wanderer robot allows it to see a spectrum of light that is similar to what humans perceive. With two sensors, the robot can monitor two directions for light level differences and be programmed to either turn to or to avoid high light levels.

In this guide I will show how to add the CdS photocells to the Tiny Wanderer and provide a program for “moth” or “anti-moth” behavior. From this point it is a short step to experiment with making the classic Braitenberg vehicles.

Adding CdS photocell sensors to your Tiny Wanderer robot allows it to see a spectrum of light that is similar to what humans perceive. With two sensors, the robot can monitor two directions for light level differences and be programmed to either turn to or to avoid high light levels.

In this guide I will show how to add the CdS photocells to the Tiny Wanderer and provide a program for “moth” or “anti-moth” behavior. From this point it is a short step to experiment with making the classic Braitenberg vehicles.

Relevant parts
  • Insulated, stranded 22-26 gauge wire: 9 inch pieces
  • Three pin single row pin connector
  • CdS photocells
  • General proto-type breadboard
  • Heat Shrink tubing
  • 150 ohm resistor
  • 1/2" size #6 screw
  • size #6 nuts
  • Small tie wraps
Tools
  • Drill and 9/64" drill bit
  • Saw
  • Small Flathead Screwdriver
  • Soldering Iron and rosin core solder.
  • Volt-Ohm Meter
  • Wire cutters
  • Wire stripper

lines.text: Use heat-shrink tubing to protect the legs of the CdS photocells. Do not heat the tubing.

lines.text: Take the wires that come from the sensor breadboard location that is farthest from the end with the mounting holes. Both wires should be connected directly to a pin of a CdS photocell. Slide a piece of heat-shrink tubing over both of the wires. The heatshrink will need to have a diameter large enough to slip over two wires. Join the wires and solder both of them to an end pin of 3-pin male pin connector.
lines.text_raw: Take the wires that come from the sensor breadboard location that is farthest from the end with the mounting holes. Both wires should be connected directly to a pin of a CdS photocell. Slide a piece of heat-shrink tubing over both of the wires. The heatshrink will need to have a diameter large enough to slip over two wires. Join the wires and solder both of them to an end pin of 3-pin male pin connector.

lines.text: Take the remaining wire from the sensor breadboard that has the resistor and slip a piece of heat-shrink tubing over it. Then solder the wire to the middle pin of the 3-pin male pin connector.
lines.text_raw: Take the remaining wire from the sensor breadboard that has the resistor and slip a piece of heat-shrink tubing over it. Then solder the wire to the middle pin of the 3-pin male pin connector.

lines.text: Slide a piece of heat-shrink tubing over the end of the last wire, which should be connected to one end of the CdS photocell on the sensor board without a resistor. Solder this wire to the other end pin of the connector.
lines.text_raw: Slide a piece of heat-shrink tubing over the end of the last wire, which should be connected to one end of the CdS photocell on the sensor board without a resistor. Solder this wire to the other end pin of the connector.

lines.text: Pull the heat-shrink tubing over the solder joints and apply heat to shrink the tubing in place.
lines.text_raw: Pull the heat-shrink tubing over the solder joints and apply heat to shrink the tubing in place.

lines.text: Finally, mark the wire on the end connector pin that has only one wire attached to it with a red felt-tip marker to indicate pin #1 of the connector.
lines.text_raw: Finally, mark the wire on the end connector pin that has only one wire attached to it with a red felt-tip marker to indicate pin #1 of the connector.

lines.text: Mount the long sensor arms that come with the Tiny Wanderer kit vertically using the slots that are located in the back piece of the sensor tray.
lines.text_raw: Mount the long sensor arms that come with the Tiny Wanderer kit vertically using the slots that are located in the back piece of the sensor tray.

lines.text: Use small tie wraps to connect the sensor breadboards to the sensor arms. The CdS photocells should be located towards the back of the robot. The sensor board with the resistor should be on right when facing the front of the robot.
lines.text_raw: Use small tie wraps to connect the sensor breadboards to the sensor arms. The CdS photocells should be located towards the back of the robot. The sensor board with the resistor should be on right when facing the front of the robot.

lines.text: Each sensor should be pointed out slightly from the side of the robot.
lines.text_raw: Each sensor should be pointed out slightly from the side of the robot.

lines.text: Insert the 3-pin male pin connector into the female pin connector marked "Sensor L" on Tiny Wanderer's controller board.
lines.text_raw: Insert the 3-pin male pin connector into the female pin connector marked "Sensor L" on Tiny Wanderer's controller board.

lines.text: The picture shows the connector for the optional bump sensor (see Bump Sensor for the Tiny Wanderer) inserted into the female pin connector marked "Sensor R".
lines.text_raw: The picture shows the connector for the optional bump sensor (see [guide|1912]) inserted into the female pin connector marked "Sensor R".

lines.text: Disconnect the servos and program the robot.
lines.text_raw: Disconnect the servos and program the robot.

lines.text: You may have to change the threshold value located in the <tt>.h</tt> file. Increasing the value requires the difference between sensor values to be larger before the robot will turn. It adjusts both for sensitivity and for some sensor mismatch.
lines.text_raw: You may have to change the threshold value located in the ``.h`` file. Increasing the value requires the difference between sensor values to be larger before the robot will turn. It adjusts both for sensitivity and for some sensor mismatch.

lines.text: After programming the robot, reconnect the servo leads.
lines.text_raw: After programming the robot, reconnect the servo leads.

lines.text: Play with your robot.
lines.text_raw: Play with your robot.

guide.summary: Add a pair of CdS photocell sensors to your Tiny Wanderer and demonstrate "moth" and "anti-moth" behavior.
guide.title: Tiny Wanderer "Moth"

tools.text: Soldering Iron and rosin core solder.
